question: A 32 yr old man present to ER with history of high-grade fever, dyspnea and fatigue. On physical examination reveals a new holosystolic murmur that is best heard over cardiac apex. Skin examination shows following skin lesion. What is most likely diagnosis?
exp: Janeway lesion are nontender, macular and erythematous lesions on palms and soles of patient with acute infective endocarditis. Osler nodes are tender, violaceous nodules typically located in pulp of fingers and toes seen in patient with infective endocarditis. Libman Sack endocarditis occurs in up to 25% of patient with SLE. This condition can cause small cardiac valvular vegetations on wither side of a valve, resulting in fibrotic valve thickening in fibrotic valve thickening anf deformity. SLE may cause an acute coronary syndrome at young age even with angiographically normal coronary aeries. Rheumatic fever can lead to mitral stenosis, which is characterize by a late, rumbling, diastolic murmur at cardiac apex. Numerous symptoms are associated with acute rheumatic fever, these can be: fever, erythema marginatum, valvular damage, increase ESR, joint pain, Subcutaneous nodule and Sydenham chorea. Erythema marginatum is a nonpruritic, circular, pink eruption on the trunk that is present in few cases of acute rheumatic fever. Kaposi sarcoma: a vascular tumor that is the most common neoplasm in patients with AIDS. The lesions of KS are characterized by the proliferation of spindle-shaped cells that express markers of both endothelial cells (vascular or lymphatic) and smooth muscle cells.

question: Most friable vegetation is seen in:
exp: The hallmark of infective endocarditis is the presence of friable, bulky and potentially destructive vegetations containing fibrin, inflammatory cells and bacteria or other organisms on the heart valves.

question: Which of the following is not a complication of infective endocarditis?
exp: Myocardial infarction is rarely seen as a sequelae with infective endocarditis.

question: A 40-year-old man with a history of intravenous drug abuse develops rapidly progressive right-sided heart failure. These symptoms are most likely due to which of the following conditions?
exp: Tricuspid insufficiency secondary to bacterial endocarditis is one of the most common complications of intravenous drug abuse. Intravenous drug abusers inject pathogenic organisms along with their illicit drugs. In such patients, 80% have no underlying cardiac lesion and the tricuspid valve is infected in half of cases. Septic pulmonary emboli characterize tricuspid valve endocarditis in drug addicts. Despite antibiotic therapy, a third of cases of endocarditis caused by S. aureus are fatal. Other risk factors for bacterial endocarditis include aging, diabetes, pregnancy, transient bacteremia and prosthetic valves. The most common predisposing condition for bacterial endocarditis in children is congenital heart disease. The other choices primarily affect the left ventricle. Tricuspid stenosis is distinctly uncommon and does not occur rapidly.

question: Which of the following is not commonly associated with non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE)?
exp: Hypercoagulable states are the usual precursor to NBTE. These include APLA syndrome, SLE, chronic disseminated intravascular coagulation, hyperestrogenic states, and those associated with underlying malignancy, paicularly mucinous adenocarcinomas. IV drug abuse is more commonly associated with infective endocarditis (IE); S. aureus being the major offender in IE among intravenous drug abusers.
